resources.string: This course contains a pre-test which you need to complete before you can view the full course.
Are you sure you want to delete this course? It will completely remove the course from your phone.
Are you sure you want to reset this course? It will remove all the progress logs for this course.
You might add your comments about the problem below:
An unexpected error occurred forcing the application to stop. Please help us fix this by sending us error data, all you have to do is click OK.
CHN on the go has crashed
Ooooops ! CHN on the go has crashed but a report has been sent to the developer to fix this problem
Once you have downloaded the files copy them to the \'%1$s\' directory on your phone SD card.
Download each of the files below to your PC (use right click, save-as)
A small file \'%1$s\' has been placed on your phone SD card, open this on your computer and follow the instructions to download the media files and copy them onto your phone SD card.
Error connecting to server. Please check you have an active internet connection and try again.
You need an active internet connection to access this page. Please turn on wifi or mobile internet connection and try again.
You don\'t appear to have a media player installed which supports playing this video.
Error trying to download media, please try again later
\'%1$s\' does not appear to be a supported media file type.
There aren\'t any questions in this quiz.
An error occurred trying to load the course. Please reinstall the course.
You don\'t seem to have an app installed to open \'%1$s\'. Please install an app capable of opening this type of file.
Your SD card is not available - please restart this app when the SD card is available.\nThe app will now close.
Text To Speech failed. Please check your phone to ensure have Text to Speech installed and enabled
Some media files are missing for your courses.
Are you sure you want to logout?\n\nLogging out will remove all your activity logs from this phone. You will need an active internet connection to log in again.
Zinc Supplements (only for children aged 2 months – 5 years)
There are no courses currently installed
Updates are available for your courses.
Send activity logs even when this application isn\'t running
How many suggested activities to display
Show which activities you are due to complete next
1000 mg Paracetamol may be given every 4–6 hr until fever returns to normal
Give 2 tablets of paracetamol for pain
Encourage client to take between 6-10 hours of sleep every night
Otherwise, assess if mother has any breast problems
Accompany client, and have a family member accompany client to the health facility
In addition to the above clients should be advised to:
Administration, Management of Vomiting, and Other Supportive Treatment for Treatment with ACTs
Adolescent and young pregnant women (10-24 years)
Advise client to keep her body clean, especially hands, genital area and breasts to minimise infection Avoid douching, insertion of herbal products and use of tampons
Advise Mother When to Return to the Health Facility IMMEDIATELY
Advise her to rest for one hour during the day
All pregnant women should be educated and counselled on IPTp using SP on an individual basis prior to drug administration
All pregnant women with no signs clinical malaria whose pregnancies are between 16-36 weeks of gestation
1st Focused ANC visit between 8-16 weeks of gestation, ideally between 8-12 weeks of gestation
And focused ANC visit between 24-26 weeks of gestation
3rd focused ANC visit at 32 weeks of gestation
2nd focused ANC visit between 24-26 weeks of gestation
4th focused ANC visit at 36 weeks of gestation
Animal-source foods: such as meat, chicken, fish, liver, eggs, and dairy products
Answer questions: ask clients if they have any questions or concerns

Artesunate and Amodiaquine should be administered together. They may be administered either as a single dose each day OR as divided doses. If given as divided doses, half of the dose should be given in the morning, and half in the evening
As soon as she has any danger signs
Ask client to go to the health center or hospital if vomiting persists
Assess if the client has pallor
Assess if mother has of the following danger signs
Good attachment helps mother to produce a good supply of breast milk
To avoid abuse/misuse of drugs and herbs
To avoid consuming alcohol during pregnancy
Baby feels too hot or cold
If baby misses a feed you should express some milk to breast soft
Baby should now take a big mouthful of breast milk
Baby should be put to the breast within the 1st hour of birth
Baby’s lower lop is turned outwards
Check BP: is it systolic BP <90 mmHg
Breastfeeding frequently day and night: at least 10 times in 24 hours; or as often as and for as long as baby wants
Part of the breast is painful, swollen and red
Breast milk provides all the food and water a baby needs for the first 6 months of life
Breastfeed baby on demand, both day and night, at least 8 – 12 times each day
Check if mother has received Vitamin A. If not and Vitamin A is available, provide one dose to the mother and record care given in maternal health or “Red” book.
Check Temperature. Does the mother have a fever > 38C?
Does the client have any of the following symptoms?
Use condoms consistently and correctly. Consult a family planning counselor
If one or both breasts become painful or hot to the touch, you should contact a health care provider
Continue to feed until baby finishes the breast and comes off on his or her own. Offer the other breast and let baby decide if he or she wants more or not
Convulsions or fits (abnormal movement of any part of the body)
Counsel mother on what to do for breast engorgement
"Counsel client to eat foods rich in iron and folate + vitamin C "
Counsel client on how to prevent common breastfeeding problems:
Counsel client to eat foods rich in calcium, iron, folate and vitamin C:
Counseling and Follow-up after Treatment of Uncomplicated Malaria
Counsel client to make every effort to deliver in a facility but in case the unexpected happens, then counsel client on what she needs to prepare for a home delivery
Counsel mother on benefits of postpartum family planning, and importance of birth spacing before having other children
Counsel mother on how to manage cracked nipples
Counsel mother on good breastfeeding practices
Counsel mother to sleep under an insecticide treated net every night with her baby
Counsel pregnant woman how to give home care after baby is born, which include
Counsel client to seek prompt treatment when they have a fever with or without any of the above symptoms
Counsel client to comply with treatment to avoid development of resistance of antimalarial drugs
In addition client should be counseled to return to a health facility if she has:
Courteous and kind: treat her and (her family member) with respect and sympathy
Danger signs and to return for follow-up after treatment is completed or if her conditions worsens
Does mother have any of the following symptoms?
Note: The last dose of SP can be administered up to the time of delivery without any safety concerns.
1st dose at >16 weeks gestation. The 1st dose should be administered by a midwife, therefore, refer clients to the health facility
2nd dose at least one month after 1st dose
3rd dose at least one month after 2nd dose
4th dose at least one month after 3rd dose
5th dose at least one month after 4th dose

New GHS guidelines indicate that pregnant women should take up to 5 doses of SP for antimalarial prophylaxis. A single dose compromising 3 tablets of 500 mg sulfadoxine + 25 mg pyrimethamine should be taken with clean water. Ensure pregnant clients eat BEFORE taking the medicine, as some women can experience weakness when taken on an empty stomach. The following is the dosage schedule for SP:
Drink 6-8 glasses of liquids a day. Avoid taking tea or coffee with meals and limit the amount of coffee you drink during pregnancy
The drug should be taken twice per day in divided doses, and after eating meals
Eat 3 meals each day + 1 extra small meal or “snack” (food taken in between main meals).
To eat foods rich in iron and folic acid + vitamin C
Educate client to keep her environment clean
Educate client on the importance of sleeping under an insecticide treated net every night
Educate client to go to the health center when she has the following signs of labour:
Educate her on the importance of taking full dose of drugs in order to clear the parasites from the blood, and thus prevent progression of disease to complications like anemia
Educate client on safe preparation of food:
Emphasize importance of going to the nearest facility immediately after delivery with newborn baby for appropriate care
Are you encountering a client who has given birth in her home or community in the last 2 weeks
Encourage client to undertake moderate exercise regularly, especially if her daily activities do not entail much physical exercise
Exclusive breastfeeding during the first 6 months protects you from getting pregnant as long as periods have not returned. Consult family planning counsellor as soon as possible after giving birth
Slowly bend your knees, keeping your back straight, and keeping your knees and feet apart.
Lie on you back with your knees bent, feet flat on the floor, and your arms at sides
Raise your head and shoulders and tighten your abdominal muscles. Hold for count of 5. Do not hold your breathe
Tighten the muscles around your anal opening and in your vagina (as if you holding back urine). Hold for a count of 3, then relax.
This exercise can be done anytime during the day when you are sitting down.
Curve your arm over your it, and then return to the original position
Rib cage lift: strengthening leg muscles and making it easier to breathe
Stand while on to something to help you keep your balance. Keep feet apart.
Rise slowly, keeping hold of the object for balance.
Factors affecting mother-to-child transmission of HIV
Family planning, STI prevention, exclusive breastfeeding, recognizing danger signs
Feeding your baby only breast milk for the first 6 months helps to space births in a way that is healthy for both you and your baby
Fever or history of fever present within the last 2-3 days
With Fixed-Dose Combination Therapy: 2 tablets once a day for 3 days for adolescents and adults
Follow up with client in 2 weeks, and refer her to the nearest health facility to check Hb
Follow up with client in a few days to see if there is improvement. If not, refer mother to see a midwife at the health center
Follow up with client after discharge from health center or hospital
Follow-up with client within 24 hours; if she is not improving refer client to the health center or hospital
Frequent feeding will help your body to produce breast milk
Feed frequently to prevent breasts from becoming swollen
Fruits like oranges, pineapples, mangoes, or bananas
Gently relax your abdomen and buttocks, allowing the curve of your back to return
Go to the health facility as soon as danger signs occur
Good attachment helps to ensure that baby suckles well
Good attachment helps prevent sore and cracked nipples
Good hygiene (cleanliness) is important to avoid diarrhea and other illness
Hb 7-11 g/dL, if possible to measure
Hb <7 g/dL, if possible to measure
Head and Shoulder Lift: strengthens muscles in the abdomen
Health education should be individualised: provide the client appropriate counseling specific to her gestational age and specific problems identified
Healthy timing and spacing of pregnancy means waiting at least 2-3 years before becoming pregnant women
Help client on complication readiness plan, specifically on:
If you are HIV-infected, your health care provider will counsel you on your care and treatment, and on how best to feed your baby
If you are HIV-infected, you need extra food to give you extra energy
To know your HIV status, you must take a test
tHow long have you had a fever?
How often should a client breastfeed:
Identify a midwife, nurse or a birth attendant in the neighborhood, and another family member or friend to care for the baby immediately after birth
If more than 7 days, have you had a fever every day?
If mother has given birth in the last 8 hours, check uterus

If mother is HIV-infected, she should not feed her baby from a nipple that is cracked or bleeding. Instead, she should feed from the other breast and express and discard milk from the breasted that is affected
If you develop cracked nipples, put some breast milk on them. Do not use any types of creams or ointments except when prescribed by a health care provider

If vomiting occurs within 30 minutes, the dosage of medicine should be repeated. If vomiting stops, give client the 2nd and 3rd doses to take at home if you are sure that your instructions will be followed
Immunised during childhood: 1 dose of TT/Td
Immunised during school age: 1 dose of TT/Td
Immunised during infancy: 2 doses as above
Exclusive breastfeeding means giving only breast milk, and nothing else (no other milks, foods or liquids, not even sips of water), except for medicines prescribed by a doctor or nurse.
Importance of knowing your HIV status
The importance of drugs that health workers give to pregnant women, why they are given, and how they should be taken
Importance of taking malaria drugs and what the dosage of drugs and when to take them
Importance of sleeping under an ITN every night with her baby
Important to feed baby the first yellowish milk known as colostrum

Inform client when to return to a health center, hospital, or CHPS facility: Advise her that a midwife will check for a number of issues as part of focused ANC visits. The client should ideally consult a midwife during the following times during pregnancy:
Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPTp) with Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine (SP) for Pregnant Women
Take iron and folic acid supplements for 6 weeks after giving birth

Intermittent prevention treatment (IPTp) schedule with sulfa-doxine pyramethamine (SP) should be followed if it has previously been started, or should be started at next visit if not started previously
How to keep the baby warm, and what good sleeping positions are
Keep expressed breast milk in a cool place, but not longer than 6-8 hours
strengthens muscles that help make delivery easier, and reduces the chance of complications during delivery.
Legumes: such as beans, lentils, peas, groundnuts, and seeds such as sesame
Listen and ask: ask client first what she knows about pregnancy and childbirth, before telling them what she should do.
Look at conjunctiva, nail bed, tongue, palmar
To make sure baby is attached well
These maybe followed by fever, chills, perspiration, anorexia, vomiting and worsening malaise.
Meat (especially liver, kidney, and other organ meats)
More money because you have fewer children, and thus fewer expenses for school fees, clothing, food, etc.
More time to breastfeed and care for each child
More time for your body to recover between pregnancies
For mother and baby to sleep under ITN every night
Mother can see more of the darker skin (areola) above the baby’s mouth than below
Need for ear piercing and circumcision
Need for rest, drinking plenty of fluids and eating more
What clients need to know about breastfeeding:

Mixed feeding (combining breast milk with anything else) is not healthy for the baby before 6 months of age. Mixed feeding reduces the amount of milk that you can produce and also can make the baby sick
If client is not due for a scheduled visit, and does not have with any danger signs provide anti-malarial treatment:
Note: Pregnant women can also present with symptoms (such as dizziness, poor appetite, etc), which are not typical symptoms of malaria but may be the only indication they have clinical malaria
Observe a feed. Check for positioning and attachment
Oils and fats such as margarine, butter, palm oil, shea butter and other vegetable oils improve the absorption of some vitamin and provide extra energy.
OR Artemether + Lumefantrine tablets with the following doses:
OR Artesunate + Amodiaquine. These drugs may be taken with high energy drinks, like glucose.
OR oral Quinine 10 mg/Kg body weight three times daily (up to a maximum of 600 mg daily) for three days + 300 mg of Clindamycin three times daily for 3 days
Oral Quinine 600 mg 8 hourly for 7 days
Pain in calf with or without swelling
Get down on your hand and knees
Pull in your abdomen and lift your buttocks. Hold for a count of 5
Pelvic Rock: helps relieves backache and pressure in the abdomen, and strengthens muscles in the abdomen
Plan for transport, which family member(s) will accompany mother & baby and where to go if complications occurs
Position and attach baby correctly on the breast. Breastfeeding should not hurt
If possible, give client iron and folate supplements: 1 iron tablet to be taken twice daily + 1 folic acid tablet to be taken once daily
Preferable to administer medicine after the client has eaten a meal
Preferable that client takes the first dose of the drug in front of the nurse or health worker

During pregnancy malaria may also be associated with womb contraction or even start of labour and increased or reduced fetal movements. Most of these signs and symptoms are non-specific and may occur with other infectious condition such as viral infections.
Pregnant women with the following conditions should be exempted from using SP
Pregnant women with sickle cell disease
If you has any trouble practicing exclusive breastfeeding, discuss with a trained counselor
To protect the baby, the mother must know her HIV status
Protect yourself and your baby form HIV and other sexually transmitted infections during pregnancy and while you are breastfeeding by practicing safe sex
Explain purpose of Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPTp) during pregnancy
Put client on her left side with her legs high above the chest
Questions or concerns about her pregnancy or the baby
Quickly bring breast from below, aiming nipple up towards the roof of the baby’s mouth
Record care given in client’s maternal health or “Red” book.
Record clinical information in client’s maternal health or “Red” book. If possible, also fill out referral form
Cord is red or draining pus
Refer client to a health center or hospital for treatment
Refer mother and baby to a health center or hospital IMMEDIATELY
Register mother & baby for health insurance or renew your NHIS. Save money for care and transport
Getting infected or re-infected with HIV while breastfeeding increases the risk of mother to child transmission. Important to practice safe sex by using condoms consistently and correctly
Report any adverse reactions to the drugs immediately
This is reserved for clients who do not tolerate Artesunate-Amodiaquine
What is the result of the malaria test?
If client is due for a scheduled PNC visit, refer her to see a midwife
To go for scheduled PNC visits
If given as SINGLE DAILY DOSING:
Skin sores and pus from eyes
To sleep under an insecticide treated net every night with her baby
Sleeps too much or hard to wake
Standard 3-day treatment with a total of six doses according to body weight is recommended as below:
Staples: grains such as maize, wheat rice, millet, sorghum, and roots and tubers such as cassava and potatoes
Explain effects of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and HIV/AIDS, specifically on:
How to prevent of STIs, including HIV
Educate clients on what supplements to take
Swollen joints or limbs or skull
Tablets of each drug come packaged together.
Takes analgesics as prescribed, e.g. paracetamol 1 g (2 tablets) every 6 hours, if needed
Take de-worming tablets to treat worms and help prevent anoemia
Take iron and folic acid supplements during pregnancy and for at least 3 months after
Target groups for IPTp using SP include:
Teach mother how to keep the baby warm on the way to the health facility
Treat client with Artesunate-Amodiaquine (see section 10.2). If they cannot tolerate it, then alternate drugs include Artemether-Lumefantrine or Dihydroartemisine-Piperaquine
Treatment for Uncomplicated Malaria in Pregnant Women
Treatment of fever with Paracetamol is a recommended part of supportive care for malaria. Paracetamol in tablet form may be given every 4-6 hours until the temperature is normal.
TT2: At least 4 weeks after TT1
TT5: At least one year after TT4
If given as TWICE DAILY DOSING:
Use clean utensils and store foods in a clean place
Use clean cotton underwear, and use loose fitting clothing
Use ITNs and other preventive measures
Vitamin A rich fruits: such as mango, papaya, passion fruit, oranges, banana, pineapple, avocado, watermelon, and tomatoes
Vitamin A rich vegetables: such as dark-green leaves, carrots, yellow sweet potato and pumpkin, eggplant, and cabbage
Wait until baby’s mouth open wide
Wash your hands with soap and water before preparing foods and after using the toilet
Wash raw fruits and vegetables before eating
Wash vegetables, cook immediately to preserve nutrients
Watch for signs of diarrhoea, fever, difficulty breathing, or refusal to feed because these need prompt attention
When baby is 6 months old continue breastfeeding and begin giving other foods
When speaking to client, keep in mind:
You will know if baby is taking enough breast milk if he or she passes light-coloured urine at least 6 times a day and is gaining weight
Wipe genitals from front to back (vulva to anus)
Women in their 1st trimester of pregnancy (first 3 months)
Women who are known to be allergic to sulphur-containing drugs or pyrimethamine component
Women with HIV/AIDS who have been put on cotrimoxazole for opportunistic infections
Women known to have severe liver disease
Women known to have Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) enzyme deficiency, either full or partial defect
For women who were NOT previously immunized
Women in their pregnancy and in their 1st trimester are at greater risk of developing clinical malaria. The following signs and symptoms may occur:
Women with pregnancy beyond 36 weeks (8 months) gestation
For women who were previously immunized
Women who receive SP should be educated on the potential adverse effects and what to do when these arise
Women who have received treatment with sulphur-based drugs, e.g. cotrimoxazole within 4 weeks of being seen at the clinic
Women who refuse IPTp using SP for any reason should NOT be discriminated against, and should be counseled to use ITN
Women with first or second pregnancies
You must be connected to a wifi network to download the media files.\nPlease connect to a wifi network to download the media files on your phone, or download the files via your PC.
Thank you for completing the pre-test. You can now continue to the course.
Press the image to view larger version
Please give an answer before moving to the next question
